conclusion: The gas is an ideal gas. The temperature at state C is \( T_C = 300 \, \text{K} \). The pressure and volume at state C are \( p_C = 4 \times 10^3 \, \text{Pa} \) and \( V_C = 2 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).
The ideal gas law is given by \( pV = nRT \) where \( p \) is the pressure, \( V \) is the volume, \( n \) is the number of moles, \( R \) is the gas constant, and \( T \) is the temperature.

premise: Using state C: \( p_C V_C = nR T_C \)
conclusion: Calculate \( nR \) using state C: \( (4 \times 10^3 \, \text{Pa}) \times (2 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3) = nR \times 300 \, \text{K} \) resulting in \( nR = \frac{2}{75} \, \text{J/K} \).
From the graph, at state A: \( p_A = 3 \times 10^3 \, \text{Pa} \) and \( V_A = 3 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).

premise: Using the ideal gas law at state A: \( p_A V_A = nR T_A \)
conclusion: Calculate \( T_A \): \( (3 \times 10^3 \, \text{Pa}) \times (3 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3) = \left(\frac{2}{75} \, \text{J/K}\right) T_A \) resulting in \( T_A = 337.5 \, \text{K} \).
The temperature of the gas in state A is \( 337.5 \, \text{K} \).
